title: The Beasley letter........ Beezley?
question: In 2011 I and my Lawyer filed a chapter 7 and my debts at that time were discharged.
answers: More information would be needed to verify if the debt was listed, an abstract of judgment was recorded and if creditors were paid to determine the effect of the lien. You will need a lawyer to review the file documentation to make any determination.

I am going to assume that since your attorney did not know the lien existed then a motion to avoid the lien was never filed. My feeling is that you need to reopen your case and have a lien avoidance motion filed. You really do need to speak with an attorney and not only have the judgment reviewed, but also your bankruptcy petition and schedules to ascertain if the lien can be avoided.

This isn't really so much a Beezley issue has simply a credit reporting that shows that a judgment was obtained. Nothing in your posting suggests that you were unaware of the existence of the claim at the time of the bankruptcy, but rather that it is still showing in the credit report.

There is no obligation on the part of creditors to remove accurate information that was previously reported, only to accurately report the current state. If the debt is been discharged, it should be reported as such. If it is still showing as a judgment recorded in the office of the county recorder, you may wish to record a copy of your discharge so as to show that while there was a judgment, it was discharged.

If you owned real estate at the time of the recording of the judgment in the office of the County Recorder for the county were the property was located, it would have created a judgment lien. Judgment liens can be avoided by reopening the bankruptcy case if necessary, provided that the judgment lien impaired your ability to claim a homestead.

But if you acquired real property after the bankruptcy, then no valid lien was ever created and you need only record the discharge to show that the debt had been extinguished.

In light of the complexity of your situation, I would suggest you consult with either the attorney who originally handled your bankruptcy or other competent counsel versed in bankruptcy matters.

Debts that are discharged in bankruptcy should appear on credit reports with a notation that the debt was discharged in bankruptcy. Judgments that are entered against a defendant prior to a bankruptcy case are not erased, as though they never existed; they are simply discharged per the order of the bankruptcy court, and the judgment debtor does not have to pay those judgments.

You also wonder how to avoid having to report an "open" judgment -- I do not think that litigators or bankruptcy attorneys refer to a court judgment as being "open" or "closed." (A particular CASE may be "open" or "closed" but that is not how judgments are described.)

A judgment is enforceable if the judgment has not been paid or satisfied. It is no longer enforceable once its been paid OR discharged in a bankruptcy case. If I were in your situation, I would seek advice on how to handle this issue from someone who is knowledgeable about type of license you are applying for. I doubt this is the first time that this issue has come up.

Under Beezley (IN RE BEEZLEY | 994 F.2d 1433 (1993) | 2d143312224) an omitted debt in a no-asset Chapter 7 case is discharged even if the creditor receives no notice of the bankruptcy. In your case, you mention that the debt became a judgment pertaining to an office lease. If you owned real property at the time of your filling, and the judgment was recorded as a lien against your real property, the lien survives even if the debt is discharged. The solution to your problem requires an analysis by an experienced bankruptcy lawyer. Find/consult/hire a lawyer using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some of us offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it.
You need to see an attorney who can review the status of the judgment and advise you properly. The Beezley decision may apply if you filed bankruptcy and you don't own real estate.
